conclusion: To determine when the two objects are farthest apart, we need to analyze the velocity-time graph and understand the relationship between the positions of the objects.

premise: The position of each object can be determined by the area under the velocity-time graph.
conclusion: The area under the curve for each object represents the distance traveled by that object.

premise: The farthest apart the two objects will be is when the difference in their positions is maximized.

premise: The slope of the tangent line at any point gives the instantaneous acceleration of the object at that point.
conclusion: The point where the tangent line to the velocity-time graph of object A is parallel to the tangent line to the velocity-time graph of object B is the point where their velocities are equal.

premise: At the point where their velocities are equal, the objects are closest to each other because their relative velocity is zero.
conclusion: The objects are farthest apart when the difference in their positions is maximized, which occurs before their velocities become equal.
